vapor_pressure¶

Created on Mon Sep 30 23:04:44 2019

@author: yoelr

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Antoine(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Antoine equation.

Parameters
a, b, cfloat

Regressed coefficients.

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

rac{B}{T+C}

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [R69b72d6e54de-2], at 100 K:

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(a=8.7687, b=395.744, c=-6.469)
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.7687
 b: 395.74
 c: -6.469
>>> f_antoine(100)
34478.367349639906

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [R69b72d6e54de-2], at 180 K

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(a=8.95894, b=510.595, c=-15.95)
>>> f_antoine
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.9589
 b: 510.6
 c: -15.95
>>> antoine(180)
702271.0518579542

Oxygen at 94.91 K, with coefficients from [R69b72d6e54de-3] in units of °C, mmHg, log10, showing the conversion of coefficients A (mmHg to Pa) and C (°C to K)

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(6.83706+2.1249, 339.2095, 268.70-273.15)
>>> f_antoine
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.962
 b: 339.21
 c: -4.45
>>> f_antoine(94.91)
162978.88655572367
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.TRC_Extended_Antoine(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the TRC Extended Antoine equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

to, a, b, c, n, E, Ffloat

Regressed coefficients.

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

rac{B}{T + C} + 0.43429x^n + Ex^8 + Fx^{12}

x = max left(

rac{T-t_o-273.15}{T_c}, 0
ight)

Parameters are chemical dependent, and said to be from the Thermodynamics Research Center (TRC) at Texas A&M. Coefficients for various chemicals can be found in [R5646311becf4-1].

Examples

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [R5646311becf4-1], at 180 K:

>>> f_extended_antoine = TRC_Extended_Antoine(227.51, -120., 8.95894, 510.595,
...                                           -15.95, 2.41377, -93.74, 7425.9)
>>> f_extended_antoine
Functor: TRC_Extended_Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 Tc: 227.51 K
 to: -120
 a: 8.9589
 b: 510.6
 c: -15.95
 n: 2.4138
 E: -93.74
 F: 7425.9

>>> f_extended_antoine(180.0)
706317.0898414153
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner_McGraw(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner McGraw equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

a, b, c, dfloat

Regressed coefficients.

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

rac{a au + b au^{1.5} + c au^3 + d au^6} {T_r}

au = 1 -

rac{T}{T_c}

Warning

Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [R9cbfe804e6f1-2], at 100 K.

>>> f_wagner_mcgraw = Wagner_McGraw(a=-6.00435, b=1.1885, c=-0.834082,
...                                 d=-1.22833, Tc=190.53, Pc=4596420.)
>>> f_wagner_mcgraw
Functor: Wagner_McGraw(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: -6.0043
 b: 1.1885
 c: -0.83408
 d: -1.2283
 Tc: 190.53 K
 Pc: 4.5964e+06 Pa
>>> f_wagner_mcgraw(100)
34520.44601450496
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

a, b, c, dfloat

Regressed coefficients.

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

rac{a au + b au^{1.5} + c au^{2.5} + d au^5} {T_r}

au = 1 -

rac{T}{T_c}

Warning

Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [Rdf2ca0f658e0-2], at 100 K.

>>> f_wagner = Wagner(190.551, 4599200, -6.02242, 1.26652, -0.5707, -1.366)
Functor: Wagner(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 Tc: 190.55 K
 Pc: 4.5992e+06 Pa
 a: -6.0224
 b: 1.2665
 c: -0.5707
 d: -1.366
>>> f_wagner(100)
34415.00476263708
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Boiling_Critical_Relation(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Boiling Critical Relation equation.

Parameters
Tbfloat

Boiling point temperature [K].

Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

Formulation makes intuitive sense; a logarithmic form of interpolation.

References

1

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

Examples

Example as in [1] for ethylbenzene

>>> Boiling_Critical_Relation(347.2, 409.3, 617.1, 36E5)
15209.467273093938
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Lee_Kesler(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Lee Kesler equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

This equation appears in [1] in expanded form. The reduced pressure form of the equation ensures predicted vapor pressure cannot surpass the critical pressure.

References

1

Lee, Byung Ik, and Michael G. Kesler. “A Generalized Thermodynamic Correlation Based on Three-Parameter Corresponding States.” AIChE Journal 21, no. 3 (1975): 510-527. doi:10.1002/aic.690210313.

2

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

Examples

Example from [2]; ethylbenzene at 347.2 K.

>>> Lee_Kesler(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13078.694162949312
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Ambrose_Walton(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Ambrose Walton equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

Somewhat more accurate than the Lee_Kesler formulation.

References

1

Ambrose, D., and J. Walton. “Vapour Pressures up to Their Critical Temperatures of Normal Alkanes and 1-Alkanols.” Pure and Applied Chemistry 61, no. 8 (1989): 1395-1403. doi:10.1351/pac198961081395.

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

Examples

Example from [2]; ethylbenzene at 347.25 K.

>>> Ambrose_Walton(347.25, 617.15, 36.09E5, 0.304)
13278.878504306222
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Sanjari(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Sanjari equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

Although developed for refrigerants, this model should have some general predictive ability.

a[1-12] are as follows: 6.83377, -5.76051, 0.90654, -1.16906, 5.32034, -28.1460, -58.0352, 23.57466, 18.19967, 16.33839, 65.6995, -35.9739.

For a claimed fluid not included in the regression, R128, the claimed AARD was 0.428%. A re-calculation using 200 data points from 125.45 K to 343.90225 K evenly spaced by 1.09775 K as generated by NIST Webbook April 2016 produced an AARD of 0.644%. It is likely that the author’s regression used more precision in its coefficients than was shown here. Nevertheless, the function is reproduced as shown in [1].

For Tc=808 K, Pc=1100000 Pa, omega=1.1571, this function actually declines after 770 K.

References

1

Sanjari, Ehsan, Mehrdad Honarmand, Hamidreza Badihi, and Ali Ghaheri. “An Accurate Generalized Model for Predict Vapor Pressure of Refrigerants.” International Journal of Refrigeration 36, no. 4 (June 2013): 1327-32. doi:10.1016/j.ijrefrig.2013.01.007.

Examples

>>> Sanjari(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13651.916109552498
class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Edalat(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Edalat equation.

Parameters
Tcfloat

Critical point temperature [K].

Pcfloat

Critical point pressure [Pa].

ωfloat

Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

Claimed to have a higher accuracy than the Lee-Kesler CSP relationship. [1] found an average error of 6.06% on 94 compounds and 1106 data points.

References

1

Edalat, M., R. B. Bozar-Jomehri, and G. A. Mansoori. “Generalized Equation Predicts Vapor Pressure of Hydrocarbons.” Oil and Gas Journal; 91:5 (February 1, 1993).

Examples

>>> Edalat(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13461.273080743307
